div.p: Mrs. E.A.R Breck
Cor. Main & Cumberland Sts.,
Knoxville,
Tenn
Franklin, Tenn.,
My dear Mrs. Breck:
I was so glad to get your letter, & am so much obliged for the list of the Mecklenburg signers. It almost came to be an Alexanders Declaration.
Alexander is the greatest & grandest name the world has ever known, dates back to 356 years before Christ, & our branch goes back to Adam - as one of the signers has that name.
The descendants of this Adam are the Alexanders of Washington Wilkes Co.,

Ga., & considered on of the best in the state. Three sisters, married three Confederate Generals, Mrs. Lawton, Mrs. Gilmer, & Mrs. Cummings, all living in Savannah Ga., there was one brother Gen. E.P. Alexander, who has recently died.

I have sent my "tree" to Nashville to an Architect to see what I can have some copies made for. I want to make all the corrections I can, & fill out the undeveloped branches before it is copied. If any of the Knoxville kin would like copies, they must let me know. As soon as I hear from the Architect will let you know
his changes.

I have never met Laura & Sprule Lyms but know their mother & sister Mrs. Dr. Crow of Atlanta well & boarded one winter with momMary Crow. My son was born in her house. They are all unusually smart. One sister married an Czard of Va. Their uncle cvy. John Alexander lives at Tazewell Court House Va. & his brother Rev. James Harvey Alexander resides in Atlanta.
I will enclose in this a newspaper clipping which you can return. I read in the Oct. number of the Taylor-Trotwood Magazine, a very
interesting article about your father, yourself, & home. I would love dearly to have a copy of the Declaration & of Andrew Jacksons letters.

I am collecting everything I can for my son, who is now 18 yrs. old. When I am gone, there will be no one to tell him about my family. My grandfather Joseph Alexander married Elizabeth McReynolds, her people came from Scotland to Ireland. Andrew T. McReynolds was a first-cousin of Andrew Jackson, also a nephew of Gen. Chas McLean of Baltimore. His father was a prominent attorney & keeper of the Seals of Ireland, at
a salary of $25,000 a year.
Gov. Hall, who succeeded Houston a Gov. of Tenn, & who married Polly Alexander has a grandson Prest of a Bank, living in Gallatin Tenn.

Have you any records of your great-grandfathers family? On my tree it makes no mention of whom John McKnitt married. One daughter Abigail married Rev. Samuel Craighead Caldwell, his son John Madison McKnitt Caldwell married my mothers sister. Another daughter of John McKnitts, married a Ramsey - another a Wallace, one son William Bain has a large share of the tree

Now if you can fill out your branch for me, I will esteem it - a favor. Begin with - John McKnitt, giving his children, whom they married & on down to the present-day. Some day we may put it in book form. Do you know what Wallace John McKnitts daughter Mary married? Judge Jesse Wallace from East Tenn. settled here, they are fine people. Mrs. Wallace was a Heiskell. If I had my tree here could give you the names of all the family. One daughter I think married Col. I. Scott.
I hope I have not bored you with this long letter, but when I

get started on my Alexander Ancestry never know when to stop. Of course I only talk to the family about it. My husbands mother is a descendant of Ephram Brenard. His cousin Gen. George Gordon is the Commander in Chief of the Confederate Veterans.
Please excuse this miserable scrawl, I am just recovering from a severe attack of the Grippe, & am nervous. I hope you will soon be fully restored to health. With love, & best wishes.
Yours with sincerity
Nellie A. Gordon

On our tree are such names as - Baxter - Marshall - Dr. Robinson, Dr. Willson - Scott - Graham - Moore, Wallace - Dixon - Kerr - Polk, Kirkpartrick, Rev. Pharr - Barrett. Henderson - McCoy - McGanby - Harris - White - Hanson. Berry - Boggs - Dr. Rankin - Bain - Parks - Bradley - Sample - Hall - Caruthers - Garrison - Monroe - Jelton - Ozborne - & others -
